{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3593480,"name":"","username":"senditmel","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/e19adc/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-15T22:59:18.026Z","cooked":"

We will calibrate our thrifty cams, but before doing so, we wanted to know if there are any good tricks or tips anyone might know that could help improve the calibration accuracy. We were also curious if anyone using thrifty cams could share their current settings(resolution, Decimation, etc). Lastly, how much would you guys recommend twisting the thrifty cams to get a certain focus?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"updated_at":"2025-04-15T22:59:18.026Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":326,"readers_count":325,"score":70.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":499461,"topic_slug":"thriftycam-calibration","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":75132,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":false},{"id":3593911,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-16T13:30:23.250Z","cooked":"
senditmel:

Lastly, how much would you guys recommend twisting the thrifty cams to get a certain focus?

I don’t have a ThriftyCam so honestly I don’t understand your question. In general you focus a camera by pointing it at some object at the desired distance and changing the lens distance to the sensor until the object is the sharpest looking (apparently by slightly twisting the lens in the screw mount of your camera). Text and lines make a good object so maybe use an AprilTag with its ID printed with it or some other large font text at about two meters.

Limelight has a numeric sharpness measurement so I wrote a program to replicate that function including a Siemens Star for another use (I don’t know the LL algorithm but there are ones on the Internet). The research and programming was fun and entertaining but otherwise useless since I discovered the quick eyeball method was much easier to use and arguably more accurate than being pedantic about it.

// from https://github.com/tom131313/calibrate/blob/main/Focus.java

// The use of second derivatives is one technique for passing the high spatial frequencies,
// which are associated with sharp edges. As a second derivative operator we use the Laplacian
// operator.
Imgproc.Laplacian(gray, lap, 3); // highlighting distinct edges
Core.meanStdDev(lap, mean, standardDeviation); // pooling all the individual points into one value
","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"updated_at":"2025-04-16T13:30:23.250Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":291,"readers_count":290,"score":68.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":499461,"topic_slug":"thriftycam-calibration","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":false},{"id":3593959,"name":"John Fogarty","username":"JohnFogarty","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/johnfogarty/{size}/88837_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-16T14:12:55.877Z","cooked":"

What calibration results did you get? Using a online purchased Charuco board we achieved ~0.5 px reprojection error and our strategy was standing 2 feet away taking 50+ pictures of our board in different orientations so that we covered the entire calibration window with the colored dots.

For focus…
Twisting the lens until you achieve the sharpness or tracking of a target at the desired distance is all that we do.

Settings are coprocessor dependent as you likely can not use the same decimate/resolution settings we do if you don’t use the same computer we use. I’m getting an OrangePi soon so I’ll have some more generic case information/values to share soon, but what we use now is not common.

Thank you for the reply. To change the thrifty cams focus, you need to manually change the lens distance to the sensor. I was curious what teams used as a focus that works for both far-away tags and close tags(2 meters make sense). After doing so, would you recommend putting a dap of glue or tape on the side of the lens to prevent it from moving around?

We have not yet calibrated the cameras and I can get you that info tomorrow when we do. would you recommend buying a charuco board or printing one that PV gives you? Would you recommend using the PV calibration? lastly doesn’t apriltags’ distances change over the course of the match so did you guys have to find a sharpness that worked for both far and close tags?

Sharpness setup for a distance within 4-6 feet worked well enough to also see tags that were much further away. Focus with such a small lens does not require that much of a headache.

I would not use a printed one. I would either buy one or use a ipad/tablet screen and measure the square size with calipers.

Affordable Charuco Calibration Targets General Forum
Looking for a reliable and affordable way to calibrate your cameras for 2025? I’m excited to share a new product: Charuco Calibration Targets, designed specifically for teams looking to achieve professional-quality camera calibration without breaking the bank. Why These Targets? Flat and Durable: Made from 6mm aluminum composite, these targets stay flat, ensuring consistent and accurate calibration results. Cost-Effective: Comparable to professional-grade targets but at a fraction of the pric…

You have to calibrate the camera at the resolution you are going to use for tracking. The one that gives you the best framerate/latency. The board is the same no matter what resolution you use.

There is some doubt about how much pose accuracy you can get with distant AprilTags (use larger std dev). If you are determined to get the last little bit from them, then I suggest this focus strategy:

While watching the 3-D pose wire frame drawn on the AprilTag that is at the maximum distance that you want to view, turn the focus adjustment such that the 3-D pose frame appears and disappears.

Mark the spot half way between the most CW and most CCW positions that the wire frame is present. That’s where the tag can be best interpreted.

Up close tags might be a bit blurry but the first vision processing step in detecting a tag is a blur function anyway.

Verify different tags can be detected and interpreted at all distances that you want.

If the lens isn’t tight in the holder, then a dot of hot glue is appropriate. We’ve never glued but I didn’t go to World’s with the team and didn’t check the focus today so I don’t know how badly the robot and camera got beat-up on its truck ride.
